p: Irrespective of the methodological approach used to evaluate the burden of influenza, cases are disproportionately common among the youngest and oldest individuals [1], [4], [14], [15]. Iuliano et al. estimated a mean annual influenza-associated excess respiratory mortality rate per 100,000 individuals of 2.9–44.0 in people aged 65–74 years and 17.9–223.5 in people aged ≥ 75 years, compared to 0.1–6.4 in people aged < 65 years, and to an overall rate of influenza-associated respiratory deaths of 2.1–23.8 per 100,000 in children aged < 5 years [9].
